Column Comment.0: ANALYSIS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a sample analysis. Various types ofanalysis may be conducted on a sample. Samples may be derived from lithologiccuttings, fluid collection etc.
Column Comment.1: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.2: DETAIL ANALYSIS OBSERVATION NUMBER: A Unique observation number for theelemental analysis.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y or N flag indicating whether this row of data is currentlyeither active/valid (Y) or inactive/invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ANALYSIS VALUE: Value for the measurement of the analysis of the property.
Column Comment.5: ANALYSIS VALUE OUOM: Property analysis value original unit of measure (e.g.,mole percentage, BTU, etc.).
Column Comment.6: ANALYSIS VALUE TYPE: Use this column to list the type of values for the analysis,in cases where the value is text based.
Column Comment.7: ANALYSIS VALUE UOM: In cases where the UOM cannot be standardized by use ofthe meta model, the actual unit of measure for the analysis value.
Column Comment.8: AVERAGE VALUE: The average or single value assigned to this specification. If onlyone measure is provided, it should be stored here.
Column Comment.11: VALUE CALCULATED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not the value iscalculated (opposed to collected raw value).
Column Comment.12: CALCULATION METHOD IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the method or formulaused to create a calculated or derived value.
Column Comment.13: EFFECTIVE DATE: date on which the data in this row came into effect.
Column Comment.14: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.15: MAXIMUM DATE: the maximum date, such as an expiry date, that describes thisproduct.
Column Comment.16: MAXIMUM VALUE: the maximum value for a specification, such as the maximumdiameter of a tank, or the maximum load capacity of a vehicle.
Column Comment.19: ANALYSIS MEASUREMENT TYPE: A list of valid measurement types. ANL QCVALID MEASURE lists which measurement types are valid for various types ofanalysis, and what valid ranges for the values should be. In analysis detail tables,ensure that you have selected a measurement type that is appropriate for the type ofstudy.
Column Comment.20: MINUMUM DATE: the minimum date associated with a specification, such as a datethat a product cannot be used for, such as for aging processes.
Column Comment.21: MINIMUM VALUE: the minimum value associated with a specification, such asminimum pipe thickness or minimum pressure capability.
Column Comment.24: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should becreated.
Column Comment.25: PREFERRED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether the elemental detail ispreferred.
Column Comment.26: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.27: VALUE REPORTED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not the value isreported (as opposed to calculated)
Column Comment.28: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.29: STEP SEQUENCE NUMBER: A unique number indicating the sequence of the stepamong other steps in the preparation and processing of the sample. This column is asufficient method to keep track of what is done in the sample analysis. However, ifthe requirement for more complicated tracking such as two steps occurringsimultaneously or if steps are needed to be added to the initial procedure, use thetwo columns STEP_SEQ_NO1 and STEP_SEQ_NO2 in the tableANL_STEP_XREF.
Column Comment.30: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.31: VALID VALUE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether or not the value is valid.
Column Comment.32: VALID VALUE REMARK: A narrative remark about the validity of the value.
Column Comment.33: VALUE CODE: the code assigned to the value by observation, in cases wherenumeric values are not used.
Column Comment.34: VALUE DESCRIPTION: A narrative description of the value from the elementalanalysis.
Column Comment.35: VALUE QUALITY: The quality of the value, this could be effected by the calculationmethod or by the collection or analysis process.
Column Comment.36: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.37: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.38: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.39: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.40: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.41: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.42: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
